discourse_list.title: Report: Former SEC director Hinman made millions from a pro-Ethereum firm during tenure

content.content: I came across this article and thought it was of interest. Former SEC director Hinman made millions from a pro-Ethereum firm during tenure (protos.com) As per the article, a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) by a whistleblower has evidenced that former Securities and Exchange Commission  Director William Hinman was receiving millions of dollars in retirement benefits from a pro-Ethereum law firm (Simpson Thatcher & Bartlett) during his time at the SEC. Also of interest to me, as I was unaware of this, is that there is an Enterprise Ethereum Alliance. I haven’t’ had time to really look at the members but law firm wise, I saw some large firms that typically have astronomically high rates for legal services.

Wow how interesting, well sometimes you have to put pressure on the old methods, there are many such pressure groups for politicians in other industries, it is not that uncommon (I am not justifying this hehe).

I can see how sometimes one may overlook these conflicts. But, as a lawyer, one is (supposed to be) trained in ethics and this is a no brainer. There are routine disclosures that these folks typically have to execute so this is very weird.
MFeinberg:  pro-Ethereum law firm   Can North Lakes Legal PLLC and @christiancdpetersen be a “pro Maker law firm and lawyer”? If so, I am guilty.

What a thing to fail to disclose. Oops, my bad SEC, forgot to mention that on my disclosure that I have executed many times in my career. What are they teaching over there at the Enterprise Ethereum Alliance ?
In fairness this type of undisclosed conflict of interest is common in DeFi

That might be so. I can see this happening often, not just in DeFi but in the general crypto space as a whole.  However, this is the former director of the SEC (a lawyer) who was apparently warned by the SEC ethics officer about these issues. So I think this is not the normal situation.
agreed it really stinks, disclosure and ethics wise. just noting that crypto and DeFi arent so pure either

And it seems he was actually pro-eth and pro-crypto in general so that is very unfortunate. It almost makes the space look bad lol. It is possible he wouldn’t have gotten the gig if he did disclose these issues. Oh well
its a shame to see poor disclosure and ethics trip up folks, but it also makes you wonder about their motivations

I recall the Ethereum Enterprise Alliance as being a pretty big deal back around 2019 or so - back then, the idea of ‘enterprise Ethereum’ was one of the (hypothesized) killer apps for Ethereum. Fortune 500 companies were falling over each other to announce that they were going to use Ethereum as a way of cutting transaction costs, particularly in B2B. There were some efforts to try to build ‘private’ or ‘consortium’ Ethereum chains that individual businesses (Microsoft, EY I think) or groups of businesses  would use solely for internal transactions. The Ethereum Enterprise Alliance was a big player originally, but you don’t hear that much about ‘enterprise Ethereum’ anymore. These days, Fortune 500 companies are much more likely to announce a NFT drop…
Interesting. I like the name Ethereum Enterprise Alliance. It sounds like a group that could have fought against the empire in Star Wars.
